channel.title: INfinance
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from INfinance, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Oil Extends Gains Amid Middle East Tensions, Chinese Stimulus
item.description: Oil extended gains after Israeli strikes on Lebanon. Prices were are also supported by Saudi Aramco’s CEO reportedly saying he is fairly bullish on Ch...

item.title: U.S. Natural Gas Futures Move Warily Higher
item.description: U.S. natural gas futures were higher after posting their sharpest weekly drop since February last week on mild autumn weather and increased production...

item.title: U.S. Stocks Trade Lower
item.description: Stocks edged lower after all three major U.S. indexes ended last week higher, with the Dow and S&P 500 hitting fresh records Friday.

item.title: Red-Hot Bond Market Powers Wave of Risky Borrowing
item.description: Issuance of speculative-grade debt reaches nearly record levels, reflecting economic optimism.

item.title: ‘I wish Dad were here. He always had the answer’: I received $500,000 after my late father’s wrongful-death lawsuit. My adviser suggests annuities.
item.description: “I do not want incredibly high-risk investments. I want moderate risk, but something statistically stable.”

item.title: U.S. Economic Data Boost Dollar
item.description: The dollar was bolstered by strong U.S. economic indicators, said Exness.

item.title: ‘God works in mysterious ways’: I became a Nvidia millionaire playing ‘World of Warcraft.’ Am I smart — or just lucky?
item.description: “I had no job and no unemployment benefits.”

item.title: I’m 63, retired and getting $45,000 per year. But I only have about $200,000 in my IRA and still have a mortgage. What’s my move?
item.description: Have an issue with your financial adviser or considering a new one? Email questions or concerns to picks@marketwatch.com.

item.title: U.S. economy poised for somewhat slower growth, leading indicators signal
item.description: The leading indicators of the U.S. economy fell again in September because of weakness in a few key industries such as housing and manufacturing, but ...

item.title: The AI bubble is looking worse than the dot-com bubble. Here’s why.
item.description: Two different bubbles and two completely different revenue streams mean only one thing.
